{{other uses|Le Chat (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox comics character | character_name = Le Chat | image = Le Chat by Philippe Geluck. 1999.jpg | imagesize = | caption = | alt = Publicity shot of Le Chat, resting on a bureau. Drawn by [[Philippe Geluck]] | publisher = [[Casterman]] (Belgium) | debut = 1983. | creators = [[Philippe Geluck]] | full_name = | alliances = | supports = | converted = y }}
'''''Le Chat''''' ([[French language|French]] for "the [[cat]]") was a Belgian daily comic strip, created by [[Philippe Geluck]] and published in the newspaper ''[[Le Soir]]'' from March 22, 1983 until March 23, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hln.be/hln/nl/948/Kunst-Literatuur/article/detail/1564937/2013/01/19/De-Kat-verdwijnt-na-dertig-jaar-uit-Waalse-kranten.dhtml|title='De Kat' verdwijnt na dertig jaar uit Waalse kranten|website=Hln.be|accessdate=21 December 2017}}</ref>
During its run it quickly became one of the bestselling [[Franco-Belgian comics]] series and the [[mascot]] of ''[[Le Soir]]''. While virtually an icon in [[Wallonia]] he's far less well known in [[Flanders]].
==Concept== ''Le Chat'' is an adult, human-sized obese, [[anthropomorphism|anthropomorphic]] cat who typically wears a suit. He always has the same physical expression. He often comes up with elaborate reasonings which lead to hilariously absurd conclusions e.g. by taking metaphors literally or by adding increasingly unlikely ''what-ifs'' to ordinary situations.
One page in length, it appeared weekly in the "Victor" supplement of Belgian newspaper ''[[Le Soir]]''. For Le Chat's 20th anniversary in 2003, Le Soir allowed Geluck to illustrate that day's entire newspaper. An exhibition of Le Chat's history (and that of his creator), "Le Chat s'expose", was first held at the Autoworld Motor Museum in Brussels in Spring 2004, and has since toured Europe. In March–October 2006 it even appeared at Les Champs Libres in [[Rennes]].
==In popular culture== As part of the [[Brussels' Comic Book Route]] a wall in the Zuidlaan/Boulevard du Midi in [[Brussels]] was dedicated to "Le Chat"<ref>[http://jawwalchat.com] {{dead link|date=December 2017|bot=InternetArchiveBot|fix-attempted=yes}}</ref> in August 1993.
On October 11, 2008 Le Chat received his own market place in [[Hotton]] in the Belgian province Luxembourg. A statue of him, sculpted by François Deboucq, was placed in the center, depicting him holding an umbrella which rains water down from inside.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hotton.be/commune/autres-services/citoyennete/une-place-du-chat-a-hotton|title=Une Place du Chat à Hotton — Commune de Hotton|website=Hotton.be|accessdate=21 December 2017}}</ref>
On July 3, 2015 it was announced that "Le Chat" would receive his own museum.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deredactie.be/cm/vrtnieuws.francais/magazine/1.2382131|title=Le Chat de Geluck aura son musée à Bruxelles|website=Deredactie.be|accessdate=21 December 2017}}</ref>
== Bibliography == # ''Le Chat'', 2001 # ''Le Retour du Chat'', 2001 # ''La Vengeance du Chat'', 2002 # ''Le Quatrième Chat'', 2002 # ''Le Chat au Congo'', 2003 # ''Ma langue au Chat'', 2004 # ''Le Chat à Malibu'', 2005 # ''Le Chat 1999,9999'', 1999 # ''L'Avenir du Chat'', 1999 # ''Le Chat est content'', 2000 # ''L'Affaire le Chat'', 2001 (Available in English as "The Cat's travels" in 2010) # ''Et vous, chat va ?'', 2003 # ''Le Chat a encore frappé'', 2005 # ''La Marque du Chat'', 2007 # ''Une Vie de Chat'', 2008 # ''Le Chat, Acte XVI'', 2010 # ''Le Meilleur du Chat'', 1994 (Available in English as "God save the Cat" in 2008) # ''L'Excellent du Chat'', 1996 # ''Le Succulent du Chat'', 1999 # ''Entrechats'', 1999 # ''Le Top du Chat'', 2009
==Sources== * {{cite book |language=French||last= Gaumer|first = Patrick|chapter =Chat (Le)|title = Dictionnaire mondial de la BD|publisher= [[Éditions Larousse]]|year=2010|place=Paris|isbn=978-2035843319}} {{Portal|Fictional characters|Comics|Belgium|1980s}} {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.geluck.com Philippe Geluck's website] *[http://www.jaimelechat.fr/ French No Official website]

page.title: List of Major League Baseball career innings pitched leaders

revision.text:
[[File:Cy Young HOF plaque.jpg|right|thumb|Cy Young, the all-time leader in innings pitched]] In [[baseball]], [[innings pitched]] (IP) are the number of [[inning]]s a [[pitcher]] has completed, measured by the number of [[Batter (baseball)|batter]]s and [[baserunner]]s that are put out while the pitcher is on the pitching mound in a game. Three outs made is equal to one inning pitched. One out counts as one-third of an inning, and two outs counts as two-thirds of an inning. This is a list of the top 100 [[Major League Baseball]] pitchers who have accumulated the most innings pitched of all time. Cy Young is the all-time leader in innings pitched with 7,356, and the only pitcher to throw more than 7,000 innings. Pud Gavin is the only other pitcher in MLB history to throw more than 6,000 innings. ==Key== {| class="wikitable" | '''Rank''' || Rank amongst leaders in career innings pitched. A blank field indicates a tie. |- |'''Player (2018 IP)'''||Number of total innings pitched during the [[2018 Major League Baseball season]] |- |'''IP'''||Total career innings pitched |- !scope="row" style="background-color:#ffffbb"|* |Denotes elected to [[National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum|National Baseball Hall of Fame]].
|- !scope="row" style="background:#cfecec;"|'''Bold''' |Denotes active player.A player is considered inactive if he has announced his retirement or not played for a full season.
|} ==List== [[File:PudGalvin.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Pud Galvin, second all-time in career innings pitched.]] * Stats updated as of the 2018 season. {| class="wikitable" style="float:left;" |- revision.comment: /* Integrated into the Linux kernel */ Rm LUKS, full disk encryption, not a filesystem
revision.text:
{{Portal|Cryptography}} {{Primary sources|date=August 2014}} This is a list of filesystems with support for [[filesystem-level encryption]]. Not to be confused with [[full-disk encryption]].
==General-purpose filesystems with encryption== * [[AdvFS]] on Digital Tru64 UNIX * [[Novell Storage Services]] on Novell NetWare and Linux * [[NTFS]] with [[Encrypting File System]] (EFS) for [[Microsoft Windows]] * [[ZFS]] since Pool Version 30 * [[Ext4]], added in [[Linux kernel]] 4.1<ref>{{cite web|url=https://lwn.net/Articles/639427/|title=Ext4 encryption [LWN.net]|author=|date=|website=lwn.net|accessdate=23 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180219072915/https://lwn.net/Articles/639427/|archivedate=19 February 2018|df=}}</ref> on June 2015 * [[F2FS]], added in Linux 4.2<ref>https://marc.info/?l=linux-kernel&m=143517753413580 {{Primary source inline|date=June 2015}}</ref> * [[APFS]]
==Cryptographic filesystems== <!-- ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- NB! Before adding any entries to this list, please make sure the entry is itself a first-class *file system* that implements cryptography. {{original research|date=July 2017}} These mythological monarchs supposedly ruled Fib, the reigns of these monarchs are mostly legendary and begin in the 7th century BCE with king Fib. The reigns of these monarchs are attributed to the Pictish chronicles, written in the 10th century during the reign of King Kenneth II of Scotland.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://anthonyadolph.co.uk/the-pictish-king-list/|title=Pictish King List|website=anthonyadolph.co.uk|language=en-US|access-date=2017-07-09}}</ref>
==7th-4th Century BCE== {| class="wikitable" !Name !Ruled |- |[[King Fib|Fib or Fibaid]] |[[Kingdom of Fib]] |- |[[Gede-olgudach]] |[[Scone, Perth and Kinross|Scone]] |- |[[Denbecan]] | [[Celts|Celtic People]] |- |[[Oflinecta]] |[[Celts|Celtic People]] |- |[[Guidid-gaed-brechach]] |[[Celts]] |- |[[Gest-gurgich]]
|[[Celts]] |- |[[Wurgest]] |[[Celts]] |}
==4th Century CE (Pictish Kings)== {| class="wikitable" !Name !Reign !Short name !Ruled |- |[[Gartnait Ioc|Gartnait Ioc I]] |296-305 CE |[[Gartnait Ioc|Gartnait I]] |[[Pictland]] |- |[[Breth of Pictland|Breth]] |305-312 CE |[[Breth of Pictland|Breth]] |[[Pictland]] |} For later monarchs see [[List of Pictish kings|List of Pictish Kings]]. Fib became a puppet state after the reign of the only true king Fib, it was a sub-kingdom from the 7th century BCE until the 9th Century CE (691 BCE - 837/843 CE) when Pictland was united under Kenneth MacAlpin, the last king to rule Pictland before Kenneth was Drest X thus making him the last king of the Fib puppet-state.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.kjhskj75z.talktalk.net/pictish.html|title=THE PICTISH CHRONICLE|website=www.kjhskj75z.talktalk.net|access-date=2017-07-09}}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of Pictish kings]] * [[List of Scottish monarchs]] * [[Kingdom of Fib]] * [[King Fib]] * [[Fife]] * [[Pictland]]

{{Infobox professional wrestler |name=Luther Lindsay |image= Luther Lindsay.jpg |image_size=200px |caption= |birth_name = Luther Jacob Goodall |names=Luther Lindsay
Luther Lindsey |height= {{height|ft=6|in=4}} |weight= {{convert|235|lb|kg|abbr=on}} |birth_date = {{birth date|1924|12|30}} |death_date = {{death date and age|1972|2|21|1924|12|30}} |birth_place = [[Norfolk, Virginia]], U.S. |death_place = [[Charlotte, North Carolina]], U.S. |resides= |death_cause = [[Myocardial infarction]] |billed=[[Norfolk, Virginia]], U.S.
[[Los Angeles|Los Angeles, California]], U.S. |trainer=[[Stu Hart]] |debut=c. 1951 |retired= |website= |}} '''Luther Jacob Goodall''' (December 30, 1924 – February 21, 1972) was an American professional football player and wrestler, known by his ringname '''Luther Lindsay''' or '''Lindsey''', who competed throughout the [[United States]] with the [[National Wrestling Alliance]] as well as international promotions such as [[All Japan Pro Wrestling]], Joint Promotions and [[Stampede Wrestling]]. One of the first [[African American]] wrestlers to become a major star,{{cite web |url=http://www.mikemooneyham.com/pages/viewfull.cfm?ObjectID=B5BF374A-88C0-41ED-A732FB5B91606D73 |title=The Wrestling Gospel According to Mike Mooneyham - Rufus R. Jones: The 'R' Stood For 'Guts' |accessdate= |author=Mooneyham, Mike |year=1991 |publisher=MikeMooneyham.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081114082131/http://www.mikemooneyham.com/pages/viewfull.cfm?ObjectID=B5BF374A-88C0-41ED-A732FB5B91606D73 |archivedate=2008-11-14 |df= }} he was extremely popular in the [[Pacific Northwest Wrestling|Pacific Northwest]] and [[Jim Crockett Promotions|Mid-Atlantic territory]].{{cite web |url=http://www.mikemooneyham.com/pages/viewfull.cfm?ObjectID=20B379A4-3922-4B14-A1E94FA5676E616D |title=The Wrestling Gospel According to Mike Mooneyham - Tribute To Henry Marcus |accessdate= |author=Mooneyham, Mike |date=1998-05-24 |publisher=MikeMooneyham.com }} A frequent rival and tag team partner of [[Shag Thomas]], he also teamed with [[Bearcat Wright]], [[Nick Bockwinkel]], Pepper Gomez and was involved in feuds with [[Michael DiBiase|"Iron" Mike DiBiase]], [[Maurice Vachon|Mad Dog Vachon]], [[Beauregarde]], [[Lonnie Mayne|Moondog Mayne]], [[Tony Osborne|Tony Borne]] and [[Pat Patterson (wrestler)|Pat Patterson]] & [[Gene LeBell|The Hangman]]. For much of the early 1950s and '60s, Lindsay was billed as the U.S. Colored (or Negro) Heavyweight Champion and took part in the first interracial professional wrestling matches held in the United States. Between 1953 and 1956, he faced [[NWA World Heavyweight Championship|NWA World Heavyweight Champion]] [[Lou Thesz]] in a series of matches. Although largely resulting in time limit draws, he was the first African-American to make a challenge to the title and earned Thesz's respect during these bouts publicly praising his wrestling ability. He was considered one of the top submission wrestlers of his day working with [[Don Leo Jonathan]] and [[Stu Hart]].{{cite web |url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/Bios/jonathan.html |title=SLAM! Wrestling Hall of Fame: Don Leo Jonathan |accessdate= |date=2008-01-12 |publisher=SLAM! Sports }} Lindsay was one of the few men who bested him in the infamous "[[Hart Dungeon]]" and later became one of Hart's best friends. Hart reportedly carried a picture of him in his wallet until his death.McCoy, Heath. ''Pain and Passion: The History of Stampede Wrestling''. Toronto: CanWest Books, 2005. (pg. 66) {{ISBN|0-9736719-8-X}} He was held in high regard by his fellow wrestlers{{cite web |url=http://www.dutchsavage.com/dutchanswers2.html |title=Dutch's Answers, Page 2 |accessdate= |author=Savage, Dutch |authorlink=Dutch Savage |year=2003 |publisher=DutchSavage.com }} such as Lou Thesz, [[James J. Dillon|J.J. Dillon]], [[Rip Hawk]]{{cite web |url=http://www.midatlanticgateway.com/Resource_Center/interviews/rip_hawk/rip_hawk_03.htm |title=The Rip Hawk Interview |accessdate= |author=Chappell, David |year=2005 |work=Mid-Atlantic Gateway Interviews |publisher=MidAtlanticGateway.com }} and [[Les Thatcher]].{{cite web |url=http://www.georgiawrestlinghistory.com/features/conversations/lesthatcher/01.html |title=Conversations - Les Thatcher |accessdate= |author=Crimson Mask |date=March 2004 |work= |publisher=GeorgiaWrestlingHistory.com }} ==Career== ===Early career=== Luther Goodall was born on a farm outside [[Norfolk, Virginia]] on December 30, 1924. He moved to [[Sedalia, North Carolina|Sedalia]] but later resided in [[Gibsonville, North Carolina]]{{cite web |url=http://www.legacyofwrestling.com/Wrestlers_G-N.html |title=Lindsey, Luther |accessdate= |author=Hornbaker, Tim |year=2007 |work=Wrestlers - Last Names Beginning with G-N |publisher=LegacyOfWrestling.com }} and later played college football for [[Norfolk State University|Norfolk State]]''"Wrestler Luther Lindsey Is Dead"''. Daily Times-News. 23 Feb 1972 and nearby [[Hampton University|Hampton Institute]] where he was also a [[Central Intercollegiate Athletic Association|CIAA]] wrestling champion. Although excelling in athletics as an All-American Negro [[Tackle (American and Canadian football)|tackle]]-[[Guard (American and Canadian football)|guard]], state [[Racial segregation|segregation]] laws prohibited him from playing against white athletes.{{cite web|url=http://www.midatlanticgateway.com/Resource_Center/interviews/jacobs/jacobs03.htm |title=The Abe Jacobs Interview |accessdate= |author=Chappell, David |year=2005 |work=Mid-Atlantic Gateway Interviews |publisher=MidAtlanticGateway.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101217213351/http://midatlanticgateway.com/Resource_Center/interviews/jacobs/jacobs03.htm |archivedate=2010-12-17 |df= }} He played two years of professional football in [[Hamilton, Ontario|Hamilton]] and [[Victoria, British Columbia|Victoria]] for the [[Canadian Football League]]. Lindsey began wrestling professionally making his debut in 1950 or 1951. Taking the surname of his wife, Gertrude Lindsey, his earliest recorded match was against Al Tucker in [[Chicago|Chicago, Illinois]] for promoter Leonard Schwartz on November 21, 1951.{{cite web |url=http://www.legacyofwrestling.com/Results_-_Chicago_1951.html |title=Chicago Wrestling Results - 1951 |accessdate= |author=Hornbaker, Tim |year=2007 |publisher=LegacyOfWrestling.com }} As early as 1953, Lindsay was billed as the U.S. Colored or Negro Heavyweight Champion. He was one of the few African-Americans in professional wrestling and, in accordance with state segregation laws at the time, he was only allowed to travel with and compete against other African-American wrestlers during his early career. One of his most frequent opponents was [[Shag Thomas]] who he later claimed knew better than any other opponent.{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestlingperspective.com/blacklikeme.html |title=Black Like Me |accessdate= |authors=Phantom of the Ring, Paul MacArthur, David Skolnick, ed. |year=2000 |publisher=''Wrestling Perspective'' }} During the late 1950s, he became the first African-American south of [[Washington, D.C.]] to compete in a wrestling event when he faced [[Ron Wright (wrestler)|Ron Wright]] in [[Kingsport, Tennessee]]. Although the [[National Guard of the United States|National Guard]] was brought in amid fears of [[race riot|rioting]], the crowd unexpectedly favored Lindsay against Wright. As a result of Lindsay's success in the area, other African-American wrestlers were also brought into the area such as [[Bearcat Wright]] and [[Bobcat Brown]]{{cite web |url=http://www.kayfabememories.com/Interviews/ronwright-2.htm |title=KM Interviews... Ron Wright |accessdate= |author=Webber, Steve |authorlink= |author2=Ron Gott |date=2002-11-11 |work= |publisher=KayfabeMemories.com |pages= |language= |quote= }} ===Pacific Northwest Wrestling=== In early 1953, he appeared in Washington where he faced [[George Dusette]], the [[Masked Marvel (wrestler)|Masked Marvel]], [[Carl Engstrom]], [[Walter Kameroff]], [[Jack Kiser (wrestler)|Jack Kiser]], [[Bronko Lubich]], [[Axel Cadier]]. He was involved in a battle royal which included Kiser, Lubich, Cadier, [[Bud Rattal]] and [[Paul DeGalles]] in [[Yakima, Washington|Yakima]] on May 12.{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestlingclassics.com/wawli/Nos.011-020.html |title=Washington State Results, Parings - 1953 |accessdate= |year=2003 |work=The WAWLI Papers #012 |publisher=WrestlingClassics.com }} On July 24, he faced [[Lou Thesz]] for the [[NWA World Heavyweight Championship]] in [[Tacoma, Washington|Tacoma]] and the two fought to a time limit draw. This was the first of several meetings between the two champions and the first time the title was defended against an African-American opponent. A rematch one week later in Tacoma also resulted in a draw.{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/nwa/world/nwa-h-matches/nwa-h-matches1952.html |title=Records of N.W.A. World Heavyweight Championship Matches: 1952-53 |accessdate= |author= |authorlink= |year=2003 |work= |publisher=Puroresu Dojo |pages= |language= |quote= }} On October 10, Lindsay defeated [[Bronko Nagurski]] in a best 2-of-3 match during the main event at the [[Tacoma Armory]]. Nagurski had pinned him after a series of [[Professional wrestling attacks#Spear|flying tackles]] and a [[Professional wrestling attacks#Body press|full body press]], however Lindsay recovered to score the second fall after making Nagurski submit to a [[neckbreaker]]. Lindsay was eventually awarded the match when referee Freddie Steele disqualified Nagurski after refusing to break a hold. According to promoter [[Paavo Ketonen]], the winner was to receive a title shot against Lou Thesz for the NWA World Heavyweight Championship. He was one of several wrestlers who challenged the [[Seattle Ramblers]] to a football game known as the "Muscle Bowl" at [[Lincoln High School (Tacoma, Washington)|Lincoln Bowl]] on October 11. The event was attended by 7,265 fans and was successful in raising as much as $5,000 for the Associated Boys' Clubs of the Tacoma-area. Among the wrestlers who participated, a half-dozen were former [[college football|collegiate football]] stars including Lindsay, [[Pepper Gomez]] and [[Frank Stojack]]. Bronko Nagurski also participated in a dozen plays. Other wrestlers included Ivan Kameroff, the Masked Marvel, Dr. John Gallagher, The Ram, Abe Yourist and Glen Detton. Despite the addition of several players loaned by the Seattle Ramblers, most notably Mel Light, they lost the game 20-6. Lindsay injured his right [[Little finger|pinky finger]] during the game, however the wrestlers later celebrated at Steve's Restaurant. On October 16, he took part in a 7-man battle royal involving Don Kindred, Bronko Nagurski, Dale Kiser, "Red" Vagnone, Jack O’Reilly, Jack Kiser and the eventual winner Carl Engstrom. Lindsay was the fifth man eliminated in the battle royal and, that same night, fought Jack O’Reilly to a draw.{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestlingclassics.com/wawli/REDUXNos.51-60.html |title=Nagurski To Appear Here |accessdate= |author= |authorlink= |year=2003 |work=WAWLI Redux No. 55-56 |publisher=WrestlingClassics.com |pages= |language= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030407190620/http://www.wrestlingclassics.com/wawli/REDUXNos.51-60.html |archivedate=2003-04-07 |dead-url=yes |quote= |df= }} He faced Lou Thesz again in a series of matches during late-November. Their first meeting in Tacoma, on November 24, resulted in another draw however he lost to Thesz in Tacoma on November 27 and in Eugene the next night. On January 10, he won his first major title winning the vacant [[NWA Hawaii Tag Team Championship]] with [[Bobby Burns]] in Honolulu. He faced Thesz again the following spring where they fought to another draw in Portland on April 29 and Seattle on April 1, 1954. On April 9, he lost to Thesz via disqualification in Yakima.{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/nwa/world/nwa-h-matches/nwa-h-matches1954.html |title=Records of N.W.A. World Heavyweight Championship Matches: 1954-55 |accessdate= |year=2003 |publisher=Puroresu Dojo }} Later that year, he toured Northern Ontario with [[Ricky Waldo]] and [[Jim Mitchell (wrestler)|The Black Panther]].{{cite web |url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/2005/04/26/1014103.html |title=Northland Wrestling: The Golden Decade |accessdate= |author=Howard, Gary |date=2005-06-01 |publisher=SLAM! Sports }} He and [[Jack Claybourne]] won the NWA Canadian Open Tag Team titles from [[Harold Sakata|Tosh Togo]] & [[Pat Fraley]] (substituting for [[Kazuo Okamura|Great Togo]]) in Toronto on September 28. Later that year, he wrestled for promoter [[Ed Don George]] making occasional appearances at [[Buffalo Memorial Auditorium]] where he faced [[Johnny Molinda]], [[Danno O'Shocker]] and [[Danny Malone]] during the next two months.{{cite web |url=http://www.steelbeltwrestling.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=26&Itemid=44 |title=Buffalo - 1954 |accessdate= |author=Luce, Don |date=2006-04-30 |publisher=SteelBeltWrestling.com }} They lost the titles to [[Ivan Kalmikoff|Ivan]] & [[Karol Kalmikoff]] in Toronto on December 9.{{cite web |url=http://www.garywill.com/toronto/title-ctt.htm |title=Title History: Canadian Open Tag Team Title |accessdate= |author=Will, Gary |authorlink= |work=Gary Will's Toronto Wrestling History |publisher=GaryWill.com |pages= |language= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120213142631/http://www.garywill.com/toronto/title-ctt.htm |archivedate=February 13, 2012 |quote= }} The following night he fought Danno O'Shocker to a draw at the Buffalo Memorial Auditorium. This was his last match in the Buffalo area. During the summer of 1955, he and George Dusette won the NWA Pacific Northwest Tag Team Championship from [[Bulldog Curtis]] & [[Tommy Martinez]] on May 15. While still defending the tag team titles, he fought Lou Thesz to another draw in Portland on June 8. He and Dusette eventually lost the titles to [[Doug Donovan]] & Ivan Kameroff on June 11.{{cite web |url=http://www.411mania.com/wrestling/columns/27872/Official-411-Wrestling-Almanac-For-June-(Part-1).htm |title=Official 411 Wrestling Almanac For June (Part 1) |accessdate= |author=Gamble, Ron |date=2003-06-03|publisher=411mania.com }} ===NWA Texas=== Later that year, Lindsay was brought to Texas by promoter [[Morris Sigel]]. As the state began complying with national de-segregation laws, Sigel promoted the first interracial wrestling match in the state pitting Lindsay against [[Hisao Tanaka|Duke Keomuka]] in one of the biggest matches of the year.{{cite web|url=http://www.caulifloweralleyclub.org/story4.htm |title=Chapters 19-20: The Fifties |accessdate= |author=Hess, Jason |date=2002-06-23 |work=Archived Sunday Punch Columns |publisher=[[Cauliflower Alley Club]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080919145320/http://www.caulifloweralleyclub.org/story4.htm |archivedate=2008-09-19 |df= }} Lindsay would also face Lou Thesz in Dallas on September 20, 1955 in yet another draw. In January 1956, he entered the [[Dallas]]-[[Fort Worth, Texas|Fort Worth]] area then promoted by [[Ed McLemore]]. On January 10, he faced Duke Keomuka in a best 2-of-3 falls match at [[Dallas Sportatorium|The Sportatorium]]. Although taking the first pinfall, Keomuka pinned Lindsay with the help of outside interference by [[Tiny Mills]]. When referee Roy Carter was knocked unconscious outside the ring, wrestler [[Danny McShain]] made the count after Lindsay pinned Keomuka. Although controversial, the third fall was granted to Lindsay by referee decision. A week later, Lindsay met Keomuka in a best 3-of-5 falls match which stipulated that their cornermen, Danny McShain and Tiny Mills, were to be locked in cages to prevent outside interference. However, both men broke out of their cages during the match and began brawling in the ring. The four men were broken up by referees Ray Gunkel and [[Otto Kuss]] who were forced to declare a no-contest. Later during the main event between McShain and Mills, Lindsay appeared to help McShain in his match. He and McShain later took on Duke Keomuka & Tiny Mills for the [[WCWA Texas Tag Team Championship|NWA Texas Tag Team Championship]] in a best-of-3 falls match at The Sportatorium on January 24. He and McShain lost the third fall by disqualification when Lindsay threw Mills over the top rope. He returned to the area four months later teaming with [[Pepper Gomez]] in a best 2-of-3 falls match against [[Michael DiBiase|"Iron" Mike DiBiase]] and [[Danny Plechas]] as one of a series of matches for the vacant NWA Texas Tag Team titles on May 22. Plechas pinned Gomez for the third fall and, despite an argument for the match to be awarded to Gomez and Lindsay, Mike DiBiase and Danny Plechas were declared the winners. Both teams claimed the title however and a rematch was scheduled several days later. He and Gomez were forced to forfeit the match when Lindsay injured his leg during the match. Both Lindsay and Gomez faced Mike and Danny Plechas in singles matches later that night. Lindsay defeated Danny Plechas via disqualification when his partner interfered. Gomez lost his bout with Mike DiBiase when he was counted out. He was scheduled to face Duke Keomuka in the opening rounds of a tournament to meet NWA World Heavyweight Champion Lou Thesz. However, reportedly flying in from Canada, his plane was grounded due to bad weather and was substituted by Tex Brady. Defeating Duke Keomuka on December 11, Lindsay earned a title shot at then NWA World Heavyweight Champion Lou Thesz. In his tenth meeting with Thesz, the two met in a best 2-of-3 falls match at The Sportatorium on December 18. Thesz scored the first pinfall and, while Lindsay rallied to take the second, Thesz took the third fall for the victory. According to ''[[The Dallas Morning News]]'', Lindsay posted a $5,000 guarantee to face Thesz.{{cite web |url=http://www.legacyofwrestling.com/Results_-_Dallas56.html |title=Dallas Wrestling Results - 1956 |accessdate= |author=Hornbaker, Tim |publisher=LegacyOfWrestling.com }} He again met Thesz in Houston where they fought to another draw on January 20. Later that year, he also fought to a draw with newly crowned NWA World Heavyweight Champion [[Whipper Billy Watson]] in [[Dayton, Ohio]] on October 25, 1956.{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/nwa/world/nwa-h-matches/nwa-h-matches1956.html |title=Records of N.W.A. World Heavyweight Championship Matches: 1956-57 |accessdate= |year=2003 |publisher=Puroresu Dojo }} Years later while in Calgary, Watson would refuse to face him.{{cite web |url=http://slam.canoe.ca/SlamWrestlingBiosS/scott_george-can.html |title=George Scott: Before he was booker |accessdate= |author=Oliver, Greg |date=November 2001 |publisher=SLAM! Wrestling}} ===Martinez & McMahon=== In late 1957, Lindsay wrestled for promoter [[Pedro Martinez (promoter)|Pedro Martinez]] in [[Fort Erie, Ontario]]. Fighting to a draw with [[Wally Greb]] on September 21, Lindsay defeated [[Wild Bill Austin]] that same day in Buffalo. He later fought to draws with [[Joe Blanchard]] and [[Tiger Tasker]].{{cite web |url=http://www.steelbeltwrestling.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=29&Itemid=45 |title=Buffalo - 1957 |accessdate= |author= |authorlink= |date=2006-04-30 |format= |work= |publisher=SteelBeltWrestling.com |pages= |language= |quote= }} On December 17, he lost to NWA World Heavyweight Champion [[Dick Hutton]] in Dallas. In early 1959, he appeared in the [[WWE#Capitol Wrestling Corporation (1952-1963)|Capitol Wrestling Corporation]] for [[Vince McMahon, Sr.]] and [[Toots Mondt]] where he faced [[Chris Tolos]], [[Emile Duprée]] and [[Hard Boiled Haggerty]].{{cite web |url=http://superstarbillygraham.net/wrestlingresults/capitol/1959.htm |title=Capitol - NWA 1959 |accessdate= |last=Graham |first=Billy |authorlink=Superstar Billy Graham |publisher=SuperstarBillyGraham.net |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080514160249/http://superstarbillygraham.net/wrestlingresults/capitol/1959.htm |archivedate=2008-05-14 |df= }} ===Stampede Wrestling=== In 1960, Lindsay began wrestling for [[Calgary]]-based [[Stampede Wrestling]]. Feuding with [[Don Leo Jonathan]] during his first few weeks in the promotion, he defeated Jonathan at the [[Sales Pavilion]] in [[Edmonton]] on March 29. Two days later, he also beat [[Mighty Ursus]] at the [[Exhibition Auditorium]] in [[Regina, Saskatchewan|Regina]]. On April 15, he and Oattem Fisher defeated John Foti & Don Kindred for the Stampede International Tag Team Championship at the [[Victoria Arena (Calgary)|Victoria Pavilion]]. While defending the titles with Oattem Fisher, he also teamed with [[Camille Tourville|Tarzan Tourville]] who faced Mighty Ursus, Emile Koverly, Kit Fox, Jim Wright and Gypsy Joe. He and Fisher returned to the Victoria Pavilion defeated Don Kindred & Kit Fox on May 13.{{cite web|url=http://www.freewebs.com/rickvalentine/myunclechiefkitfox.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050327194606/http://www.freewebs.com/rickvalentine/myunclechiefkitfox.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2005-03-27 |title=In Memory of my Uncle, Chief Kit Fox |accessdate= |author=Valentine, Rick |authorlink= |work= |publisher=Rick Valentine: The Man You Love To Hate |pages= |language= |quote= |df= }} During the next two months, he faced [[Pat O'Connor (wrestler)|Pat O'Connor]] for the NWA World Heavyweight Championship in Edmonton, Calgary and Regina four times.{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/nwa/world/nwa-h-matches/nwa-h-matches1960.html |title=Records of N.W.A. World Heavyweight Championship Matches: 1960-61 |accessdate= |author= |authorlink= |year=2003 |work= |publisher=Puroresu Dojo |pages= |language= |quote= }} Later that year, he returned to the Capitol Wrestling Corporation. On October 1, he defeated Swede Hanson at [[Madison Square Garden]]. Teaming with Eugenio Marin against Pat & Al Smith two weeks later, he also faced Fritz Wallick the following night. On October 24, he and [[Jerry Miller|Rebel II]] fought to a draw. He and Mr. Puerto Rico teamed up against the '''Dixie Rebels''' ([[Mario Galento|Rebel I]] & [[Jerry Miller|Rebel II]]) on November 14, but lost the match. After a match with [[Tony Marino]] in [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester, New York]], Lindsay left the territory.{{cite web |url=http://www.nyprowrestling.com/results/1960.html |title=Results: 1960 |accessdate= |publisher=NYProWrestling.com }} ===Return to Portland=== The following year, he won the NWA Pacific Northwest Heavyweight Championship from [[Michael DiBiase|"Iron" Mike DiBiase]] on May 26 as well as the NWA Pacific Northwest Tag Team titles with Bing Ki Lee and Herb Freeman during the summer. On September 25, he lost the NWA Pacific Northwest Heavyweight title to [[Nikolai Volkoff]].{{cite web |url=http://www.dutchsavage.com/history.html |title=History: Pacific Northwest Heavyweight Title History |accessdate= |author= |authorlink= |year=2005 |work= |publisher=DutchSavage.com |pages= |language= |quote= }} Later that year, he traveled to [[Great Britain]]. Although his stay was brief, he scored an impressive KO victory over [[Mike Marino]] at the [[Royal Albert Hall]] and [[Josef Zaranoff]] in a later televised match.{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestlingheritage.co.uk/wrestlersl.htm |title=L - Luther Lindsay |accessdate= |author= |authorlink= |work= |publisher=WrestlingHeritage.co.uk |pages= |language= |quote= }} In early 1962, he toured Japan with [[All Japan Pro Wrestling]] where he and [[Ricky Waldo]] defeated [[Toyonobori]] & [[Rikidōzan]] for the [[All Asia Tag Team Championship]] on February 3, 1962. After losing the titles back to the former champions, he returned to the United States where he met and lost to NWA World Heavyweight Champion [[Buddy Rogers (wrestler)|"Nature Boy" Buddy Rogers]] in Seattle on June 18.{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/nwa/world/nwa-h-matches/nwa-h-matches1962.html |title=Records of N.W.A. World Heavyweight Championship Matches: 1962-63 |accessdate= |author= |authorlink= |year=2003 |work= |publisher=Puroresu Dojo |pages= |language= |quote= }} He teamed with longtime rival Shag Thomas to regain the NWA Pacific Northwest Tag Team titles defeating [[Kurt Von Poppenheim]] & [[Fritz Von Goering]] on July 21. Defeating Fritz Von Goering for the NWA Pacific Northwest Heavyweight title on August 24, he and Thomas would also regain the tag team titles four more times together between 1962 and 1964. He later lost the NWA Pacific Northwest title to [[Maurice Vachon|Mad Dog Vachon]] on October 4, 1962. He also faced [[Pat Patterson (wrestler)|Pat Patterson]]{{cite web |url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/ResultsArchive/Wrestlers/pf-patterson-pat.html |title=Wrestlers Results Archive: Pat Patterson |accessdate= |authors=Vance Nevada, Matt Farmer, Mike Rodgers, Becky Taylor, Ron Witmer and Jim Zordani |date=2008-04-29 |work= |publisher=SLAM! Sports |pages= |language= |quote= }} and [[Dean Higuchi|Dean Ho]]{{cite web |url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/ResultsArchive/Wrestlers/pf-ho-dean.html |title=Wrestlers Results Archive: Dean Ho |accessdate= |author=Nevada, Vance |authorlink= |author2=Matt Farmer |date=2008-04-29 |work= |publisher=SLAM! Sports |pages= |language= |quote= }} during their first stints in Portland defeating them both in two matches each. He and Shag Thomas regained the NWA Pacific Northwest Tag Team titles defeating Ivan Kameroff & Soldat Gorky on July 24, 1963. He and Thomas successfully defended the titles against Soldat Gorky & Dean Ho on August 9. He defeated Dean Ho in a singles match at the end of the month. On September 2, he also teamed with [[Danny Hodge]] to defeat Dean Ho & [[Dick Beyer|The Destroyer]]. Several days later, Lindsay became involved in a car accident when he smashed his car into a utility pole to avoid hitting another vehicle. Escaping from the car, he was picked up by passing motorist who brought him to a local hospital for ''"emergency surgery"''.{{cite web |url=http://www.legacyofwrestling.com/Auto_Accidents.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080930164812/http://www.legacyofwrestling.com/Auto_Accidents.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2008-09-30 |title=Wrestlers Involved in Automobile Accidents |accessdate= |author=Hornbaker, Tim |authorlink= |year=2007 |work= |publisher=LegacyOfWrestling.com |pages= |language= |quote= }} He was replaced by Hodge and lost the tag team titles to The Destroyer & [[Art Michalik]] in Salem on September 9, 1963. He and Thomas managed to regain the titles on January 15 although they eventually lost the titles back to The Destroyer & Art Michalik on January 22. Lindsay left the territory soon after. ===From Honolulu to Portland=== During a brief stint in [[50th State Big Time Wrestling]], he enjoyed a brief reign as [[NWA Hawaii United States Heavyweight Champion]] before losing the title back to [[Curtis P. Iaukea|King Curtis Iaukea]] in June 1964. On July 28, 1964, Lindsay was part of an 18-man battle royal which featured [[Gene Kiniski]], [[Harold Sakata|Tosh Togo]], [[Tor Kamata|Mr. Moto]] and King Curtis Iaukea. This event was later aired on the first episode of ''Big Time Wrestling'', a weekly television show which broadcast the first wrestling matches from the [[Honolulu International Center]], and was attended by over 14,000 fans (5,300 of these watched the event live at the Civic Auditorium). The following night, he appeared in the main event against King Curtis Iaukea for the [[NWA Pacific International Championship|NWA Hawaii United States Championship]] which sold out the Civic Arena.{{cite web |url=http://www.50thstatebigtimewrestling.com/history2.html |title=The History of Pro-Wrestling in Hawaii |accessdate= |author=Atkinson, Bill |year=2007 |publisher=50thStateBigTimeWrestling.com }} He returned to the Pacific Northwest later that year and was one of several tag team partners of [[Pepper Martin]].{{cite web |url=http://caulifloweralleyclub.blogspot.com/2007/03/little-about-2007-reunion-mc-pepper.html |title=A little about the 2007 Reunion M.C. Pepper Martin |accessdate= |author=Dollar, Morgan |authorlink= |date=2007-03-28 |work= |publisher=[[Cauliflower Alley Club]] |pages= |language= |quote= }} On October 26, he and Pepper Martin defeated [[Pat Patterson (wrestler)|Pat Patterson]] & [[Gene LeBell|The Hangman]] for the NWA Pacific Northwest Tag Team titles. He and Martin successfully defended the title against Pat Patterson & [[Don Manoukian]] and they re-lost the title to Pat Patterson & The Hangman in Portland on September 18. Lindsay and Martin continued to feud with the tag team champions defeating Patterson & [[El Shereef]] by disqualification on September 21 and El Shereef, Patterson & The Hangman in a 6-man tag team match with Dean Ho on October 5. He and Martin continued to pursue Pat Patterson & The Hangman defeating them on October 26, however they lost to them twice the following month. He and Dean Ho also lost to [[Haru Sasaki]] & The Hangman on November 10. After defeating them on November 20, Lindsay faced Pat Patterson in a singles match and fought him to a draw on December 4. After defeating El Shereef, Patterson & The Hangman in another 6-man tag team match on December 10, he defeated Pat Patterson in a singles match the following night. In early 1965, he was one of several African-American wrestlers to tour the [[Continental Wrestling Association]] with [[Sailor Art Thomas]], [[Shag Thomas|King Toby]] and [[Tiger Conway, Sr.]]. However, with segregation still in practice in the Memphis territory, they only faced each other in matches.{{cite web |url=http://www.kayfabememories.com/Regions/memphis/memphis-cwa26-2.htm |title=Regional Territories: Memphis/CWA #26, Page #2 |accessdate= |authors=Tim Dills, Edsel Harrison and David Williamson |year=2002 |work= |publisher=KayfabeMemories.com }} In Honolulu, he fought to another draw against NWA Heavyweight Champion Lou Thesz in Honolulu on May 7, 1965.{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/nwa/world/nwa-h-matches/nwa-h-matches1964.html |title=Records of N.W.A. World Heavyweight Championship Matches: 1964-65 |accessdate=|year=2003 |publisher=Puroresu Dojo }} Although teaming with Dean Ho for a time, he and Bearcat Wright defeated Enrique and Alberto Torres for the [[NWA Hawaii Tag Team Championship]] on July 28. He also regained the [[NWA Hawaii United States Heavyweight Championship]] from King Curtis Iaukea on September 29, 1965. Lindsay and Wright successfully defended the titles against Pat Patterson & [[Ray Stevens (wrestler)|Ray "The Crippler" Stevens]], as well as a tag team match with [[Neff Miavia]] on December 22, before eventually losing the tag team titles to [[Ripper Collins]] & [[Johnny Barend]] on January 4, 1966. He also lost the heavyweight title to [[Ron Reed]] the following night. This would be the only meeting between the two.{{cite web |url=http://www.georgiawrestlinghistory.com/features/conversations/buddycolt/02.html |title=Conversations - Buddy Colt |accessdate= |author=Crimson Mask |date=September 2004 |publisher=GeorgiaWrestlingHistory.com }} Between March 16-April 6, 1966, he faced [[Dale Lewis (wrestler)|Dale Lewis]], [[Dick the Bruiser]] and [[Beauregarde]] all resulting in draws.{{cite web |url=http://www.50thstatebigtimewrestling.com/results.html |title=Wrestling Results (1966) |accessdate= |author= |authorlink= |year=2007 |publisher=50thStateBigTimeWrestling.com }} ===Mid-Atlantic Championship Wrestling=== Lindsay joined a number of other African-American wrestlers in the Mid-Atlantic territory for promoter [[Jim Crockett]] and, during a televised match at the television studio in late 1966, an incident between Lindsey and [[Ike Eakins]] caused [[WDBJ]] to cancel Crockett's weekly television show ''All Star Wrestling''. Eakins reportedly used a racial slur about Lindsay. Management at WDBJ said if Eakins didn't apologize on the air the next week, they would throw the show off the air. Reportedly Eakins came out and instead of apologizing, he used the slur again and that was the last wrestling show recorded at WDBJ.{{cite web|url=http://www.midatlanticgateway.com/Almanac/tv_history/tv_studios/wdbj/studio_wdbj.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060303230027/http://www.midatlanticgateway.com/Almanac/tv_history/tv_studios/wdbj/studio_wdbj.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2006-03-03 |title=WDBJ Studio Wrestling: Television History on the Mid-Atlantic Gateway |accessdate= |authors=Dick Boune, Thom Brewer, Carroll Hall |year=2006 |work=Studio Wrestling: A Guide to TV Studios that were home for Wrestling in the Mid-Atlantic Area |publisher=MidAtlanticGateway.com |pages= |language= |quote= |df= }} However, Lindsay remained in the promotion defeating [[Pedro Godoy]] in [[Roanoke, Virginia]] on January 31, 1967.{{cite web |url=http://www.lukebrown.freeservers.com/whats_new.html |title=Match Results: 1959-1971 |accessdate= |author=Kerby, Carl |authorlink= |year=2003 |work= |publisher=LukeBrown.com |pages= |language= |quote= }} On June 2, he won the NWA Pacific Northwest Heavyweight title from Tony Borne before losing the title to Moondog Mayne weeks later. Defeating Gene Dundee at [[Grady Cole Center|Park Center]] in [[Charlotte, North Carolina]] on August 7, Lindsay also made an appearance for the [[WWE#World Wide Wrestling Federation|World Wide Wrestling Federation]] defeating [[Matt Jewell]], sometimes billed as the Negro Men's Southern Heavyweight Champion, in [[Memphis, Tennessee]] on October 30, 1967.{{cite web |url=http://www.thehistoryofwwe.com/67.htm |title=1967 |accessdate= |author=Cawthon, Graham |authorlink= |year=2005 |work= |publisher=Graham Cawthon's History of the WWE}} He and Abe Jacobs teamed up for a match against [[Pancho Valdez]] & [[The Matador]] in [[Lexington, North Carolina]] on July 6, 1968.{{cite web |url=http://johnnyweaver.blogspot.com/2007_09_01_archive.html |title=Johnny Weaver Must Not Be Sold! |accessdate= |author=Baltimore Jack |authorlink= |date=2007-09-30 |work= |publisher=JohnnyWeaver.com |pages= |language= |quote= }} Back in PNW, he and [[Dean Higuchi|Dean Ho]] lost to NWA Pacific Northwest Tag Team Champions [[Lonnie Mayne|Moondog Mayne]] & Beauregard in Portland on September 19. He also fought to draw against NWA Heavyweight Champion Lou Thesz in Salem on September 20.{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/nwa/world/nwa-h-matches/nwa-h-matches1968.html |title=Records of N.W.A. World Heavyweight Championship Matches: 1968-69 |accessdate= |year=2003 |publisher=Puroresu Dojo }} He won the NWA Pacific Northwest Heavyweight title from Beauregard, substituting for Moondog Mayne, on November 30, 1968. Lindsay and Dean Ho also teamed up to defeat NWA Pacific Northwest Tag Team Champions [[Kurt and Karl Von Steiger|Kurt & Karl Von Steiger]] via disqualification on December 21, 1968. He also teamed with Shag Thomas again to defeat the Von Steigers for the NWA Pacific Northwest Tag Team titles on February 15, 1969. Lindsay re-lost the title to Moondog Mayne on April 12.{{cite web |url=http://www.kayfabememories.com/Regions/pnw/pnw10-2.htm |title=Regional Territories: PNW #10, Page #2 |accessdate= |author=Baumer, John |year=2003 |publisher=KayfabeMemories.com }} That same year, he defeated [[Stan Stasiak]] for the NWA Canadian Heavyweight title. During early 1970, Luther Lindsay faced the original [[Minnesota Wrecking Crew]] ([[Gene Anderson|Gene]] & [[Ole Anderson]]) teaming with a number of wrestlers such as [[George Scott (wrestler)|George Scott]], [[Abe Jacobs]] and [[Randy Curtis]]. Later that year, he teamed with Curtis as well as [[Sandy Scott]] and [[Bob Ramstad]] against Gene Anderson & [[Chris Tolos]] who filled in for the injured Ole Anderson for a time. He and Gene Anderson eventually met in a singles match fighting to a time limit draw in [[Greenville, South Carolina]] on December 25, 1970.{{cite web |url=http://www.theglorydays.net/andersons/sections/history/results/eastridge/results_1970.htm |title=Mark Eastridge's Wrecking Crew Results: 1970 |accessdate= |author=Eastridge, Mark |authorlink= |date=2007-01-10 |work= |publisher=TheGloryDays.net |pages= |language= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071021095045/http://www.theglorydays.net/andersons/sections/history/results/eastridge/results_1970.htm|archivedate=2007-10-21|dead-url=yes |quote= }} Two months later, he faced NWA World Heavyweight Champion [[Dory Funk, Jr.]] in Norfolk on February 4, 1971.{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/nwa/world/nwa-h-matches/nwa-h-matches1970.html |title=Records of N.W.A. World Heavyweight Championship Matches: 1970-71 |accessdate= |author= |authorlink= |year=2003 |work= |publisher=Puroresu Dojo |pages= |language= |quote= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.midatlanticgateway.com/Resource_Center/nwa_title/1971.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071215140638/http://www.midatlanticgateway.com/Resource_Center/nwa_title/1971.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-12-15 |title=NWA Title Defenses in the Mid-Atlantic: 1971 |accessdate= |author=Bourne, Dick |authorlink= |date=2007-10-27 |work= |publisher=TheGloryDays.net |pages= |language= |quote= }} ===Death=== Lindsay scored a string of victories the following spring defeating Art Nelson, Bill Bowman, Bobby Paul, Frank Morrell and Johnny Heidman within a six-week period. Despite losing a rematch to Frank Morrell in [[Charleston, South Carolina]] on February 11, he and Frank Hester defeated Joe Soto and Tony Romano in [[Raleigh, North Carolina]] the following week. On the night of February 21, 1972, Lindsay was facing local wrestler Bobby Paul at [[Grady Cole Center|Park Center]] in Charlotte. After only ten minutes into the match, Lindsay pinned his opponent with a diving belly-flop. He apparently suffered a fatal heart attack when he made the pin and died on top of his opponent.{{cite web |url=http://www.dory-funk.com/kay-fabe.html |title=Old School Wrestling Stories |accessdate= |author= |authorlink= |year=2007 |work= |publisher=Dory-Funk.com |pages= |language= |quote= }} When Lindsay did not respond to the referee after scoring the pinfall, the police were called. Lindsay was taken back to the dressing room where he was declared dead shortly thereafter. His body was kept at his old alma mater, [[Hampton University|Hampton Institute]], for a week before his burial. His funeral was attended by several well-known wrestlers including [[Les Thatcher]] who was one of the pallbearers. On March 31, 2017, Lindsay was posthumously inducted into the [[WWE Hall of Fame]] as a part of the Legacy wing. ==Championships and accomplishments== *'''[[50th State Big Time Wrestling]]''' **[[NWA Hawaii Heavyweight Championship]] ([[NWA Hawaii Heavyweight Championship#Title history|1 time]]){{cite web |url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/us/hi/hi-h.html |title=N.W.A. Hawaii Heavyweight Title |accessdate= |author= |authorlink= |year=2003 |work= |publisher=Puroresu Dojo |pages= |language= |quote= }} **[[NWA Hawaii Tag Team Championship]] ([[NWA Hawaii Tag Team Championship#Title history|2 times]]) - with Bobby Bruns (1) and Bearcat Wright (1){{cite web |url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/us/hi/hi-t.html |title=N.W.A. Hawaii Tag Team Title |accessdate= |author= |authorlink= |year=2003 |work= |publisher=Puroresu Dojo |pages= |language= |quote= }} **[[NWA Pacific International Championship|NWA United States Heavyweight Championship ''(Hawaii version)'']] ([[NWA Pacific International Championship|1 time]]){{cite web |url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/us/hi/nwa/hi-us-h.html |title=N.W.A. United States Heavyweight Title (Hawaii) |accessdate= |author= |authorlink= |year=2003 |work= |publisher=Puroresu Dojo}} *'''[[All Japan Pro Wrestling]]''' **[[All Asia Tag Team Championship]] ([[All Asia Tag Team Championship#Title history|1 time]]) - with Ricky Waldo{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/japan/alljapan/asia-t.html |title=All-Asia Tag Team Title |accessdate= |year=2003 |work= |publisher=Puroresu Dojo |pages= |language= |quote= }} *'''[[George Tragos/Lou Thesz Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame]]''' ** Class of 2009{{cite web|url=https://www.pwinsider.com/ViewArticle.php?id=39743&p=1|title=Ricky Steamboat, Nick Bockinkel Among 2009 Class Honored By Wrestling Museum & Institute|last=Johnson|first=Mike|publisher=[[PWInsider]]|date=June 30, 2009|accessdate=November 30, 2018}} *'''[[Maple Leaf Wrestling]]''' **[[NWA Canadian Open Tag Team Championship]] ([[NWA Canadian Open Tag Team Championship#Title history|1 time]]) - with Jack Claybourne{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/canada/on/nwa/can-op-t.html |title=N.W.A. Canadian Open Tag Team Title |accessdate= |author= |authorlink= |year=2003 |work= |publisher=Puroresu Dojo |pages= |language= |quote= }} *'''[[National Wrestling Alliance]]''' **World Negro Heavyweight Championship (1 time){{cite web|url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/world/world-negro-h.html|title=World Negro Heavyweight Title|website=Wrestling-Titles.com}} *'''[[Pacific Northwest Wrestling]]''' **[[NWA Pacific Northwest Heavyweight Championship]] ([[NWA Pacific Northwest Heavyweight Championship#Title history|1 time]]){{cite web |url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/us/pnw/nwa/pnw-h.html |title=N.W.A. Pacific Northwest Heavyweight Title |accessdate= |author= |authorlink= |year=2003 |work= |publisher=Puroresu Dojo |pages= |language= |quote= }} **[[NWA Pacific Northwest Tag Team Championship]] ([[NWA Pacific Northwest Tag Team Championship#Title history|10 times]]) - with George Dussette (1), Bing Ki Lee (1), Herb Freeman (1), Shag Thomas (5) and Pepper Martin (2){{cite web |url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/us/pnw/nwa/pnw-t.html |title=N.W.A. Pacific Northwest Tag Team Title |accessdate= |author= |authorlink= |year=2003 |work= |publisher=Puroresu Dojo }} *'''[[Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame and Museum|Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame]]''' **Class of 2017http://slam.canoe.com/Slam/Wrestling/2017/05/24/22726474.html https://archive.is/zBMA3 *'''''Ring Around The Northwest Newsletter''''' **Tag Team of the Year (1961) with Herb Freeman{{cite web |url=http://www.kayfabememories.com/Regions/pnw/pnw16.htm |title=Regional Territories: PNW #16 |author=Rodgers, Mike |date=2004 |website=KayfabeMemories.com |publisher= |accessdate=}} *'''[[Stampede Wrestling]]''' **[[NWA Canadian Heavyweight Championship (Calgary version)|NWA Canadian Heavyweight Championship ''(Calgary version)'']] ([[NWA Canadian Heavyweight Championship (Calgary version)#Title history|1 time]]){{cite web |url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/canada/ab/ab-can-h.html |title=N.W.A. Canadian Heavyweight Title (Calgary) |accessdate= |author= |authorlink= |year=2003 |work= |publisher=Puroresu Dojo }} **[[Stampede Wrestling International Tag Team Championship|NWA International Tag Team Championship ''(Calgary version)'']] ([[Stampede Wrestling International Tag Team Championship|1 time]]) - with Oattem Fisher{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/canada/ab/calg-t.html |title=Stampede International Tag Team Title |accessdate= |author= |authorlink= |year=2003 |work= |publisher=Puroresu Dojo |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080505025114/http://www.wrestling-titles.com/canada/ab/calg-t.html |archivedate=2008-05-05 |df= }} **[[NWA Canadian Tag Team Championship (Calgary version)|NWA Canadian Tag Team Championship ''(Calgary version)'']] ([[NWA Canadian Tag Team Championship (Calgary version)#Title history|1 time]]) - with Ray Villmer **[[Stampede Wrestling#Hall of Fame|Stampede Wrestling Hall of Fame]]{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/canada/ab/hof.html |title=Stampede Wrestling Hall of Fame (1948-1990) |accessdate= |year=2003 |publisher=Puroresu Dojo }} * '''[[WWE]]''' **[[WWE Hall of Fame]] (Class of 2017){{cite web|title= Congratulations to the 2017 WWE Hall of Fame Legacy inductees |url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/wwe-hall-of-fame/wwe-hall-of-fame-2017/article/legacy-inductions|publisher=WWE|date=March 31, 2017|accessdate=March 31, 2017}} ==See also== * [[List of premature professional wrestling deaths]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==Further reading== *[[James J. Dillon|Dillon, J.J.]], Scott Teal and Philip Varriale. ''"Wrestlers Are Like Seagulls" from McMahon to McMahon''. Crowbar Press, 2005. {{ISBN|0-9745545-2-9}} *Erb, Marsha. ''[[Stu Hart: Lord of the Ring]]''. Toronto: ECW Press, 2002. {{ISBN|1-55022-508-1}} *[[Lou Thesz|Thesz, Lou]]. ''Hooker: An Authentic Wrestler's Adventures Inside the Bizarre World of Professional Wrestling''. Norfolk, Virginia: Wrestling Channel Press, 2001. {{ISBN|0-9706516-0-0}} ==External links== * {{wwe superstar|luther-lindsay|Luther Lindsay}} *[http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/profiles/l/luther-lindsay.html Profile at Online World of Wrestling] {{WWE Hall of Fame}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lindsay, Luther}} [[Category:1924 births]] [[Category:1972 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century American male actors]] [[Category:African-American male professional wrestlers]] [[Category:American male professional wrestlers]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Norfolk, Virginia]] [[Category:People from Gibsonville, North Carolina]] [[Category:Professional wrestlers from Virginia]] [[Category:Norfolk State Spartans football players]] [[Category:Hampton Pirates football players]] [[Category:Professional wrestling deaths]] [[Category:Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame and Museum]] [[Category:WWE Hall of Fame (2017) inductees]]
